I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
grant; (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Government of the United 
Kingdom  both  for  the  Strengthening  Public  Management  Program;  and  (iii)  proposed 
administration of a technical assistance (TA) to be provided by the Government of the United 
Kingdom for Supporting the Strengthening Public Management Program. If the Board approves 
the proposed grant, administration of grant, and TA grant, I, acting under the authority delegated 
to me by the Board, will approve the Asian Development Bank (ADB) providing the balance for 
the TA. 
 
2.  The  program  seeks  to  promote  an  enabling  environment  in  Nepal  for  the  effective 
delivery of public goods and services, especially at the local level. It will do this by strengthening 
national and local linkages in public financial management (PFM), mitigating fiduciary risks 
through greater transparency and public participation, modernizing procurement systems, and 
enhancing the effectiveness of oversight and accountability agencies. The program will support 
efforts by the government of Nepal to reform budget, fiscal, and fiduciary risk management at 
the sub-national or local government level (district development committee [DDC], municipality 
and  village  development  committee  [VDC]),  public  procurement,  and  oversight  and 
accountability  institutions  at  the  national  level.1 The  program  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  Nepal 
country  partnership  strategy  for  2010–2012  and  is  part  of  a  broader  set  of  fiduciary  risk 
reduction initiatives being implemented by other development partners in Nepal, notably the 
PFM Multi-Donor Trust Fund.2 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Nepal’s complex and protracted political transition. Nepal is continuing a difficult 
transition to democracy following the end of a decade-long civil conflict in April 2006. Given the 
deep ideological, social, and economic divisions that propelled the conflict, this transition has 
been complex and sometimes halting. It is currently at an impasse and faces major challenges. 
The country failed to approve a new constitution before a deadline on 27 May 2012, the 
constituent assembly was subsequently dissolved, and the need for new assembly elections 
have combined to prolong the transition period. This has increased political uncertainty but it 
also presents opportunities to promote reforms and help the government shape the transition.  
 
4.  Nepal’s binding constraints. Several analyses have pointed to weak governance as a 
key  constraint  to  the  post-conflict  economic  recovery  of  Nepal  and  its  further  growth  and 
development.3 The country ranks below the South Asian average on all six of the World Bank’s 
governance indicators.4 Poor governance persists largely because of the highly fragmented and 
often polarized political landscape, which makes it difficult to form durable governing coalitions 
that can focus on long-term public needs. The fragility of political coalitions consequently tends 
to foster government and management based on short-term political calculations rather than the

public interest to keep the coalitions intact. Partisan battles frequently dominate and distort 
public policy making and bureaucratic leadership.  
 
5.  Nepal’s acute economic challenges. Nepal continues to have the weakest performing 
economy in South Asia. Its per capita gross national income in 2011 was estimated at $540 (in 
current prices), compared with $770 for Bangladesh, $1,410 for India, $2,580 for Sri Lanka, 
$2,070 for Bhutan, and $6,530 for the Maldives.5 Nepal’s economy grew by 4.6% in FY2012, up 
from 3.8% in FY2011, mainly due to growth in the agriculture and service sectors and increased 
remittance inflows.6 While the incidence of poverty has declined, 25% of the country’s people 
still live below the national poverty line as of 2011. Income inequality is also high and the Gini 
coefficient for the country stood at 0.35 in 2011.7 
 
1.  Assessment of Nepal’s Public Financial Management System 
 
6.  Gaps in Nepal’s public financial management system at the national level. Results 
of a public expenditure and financial accountability (PEFA) assessment conducted in 2008 
illustrated the weak state of governance in Nepal. The country scored an A on only 1 of the 31 
PEFA indicators (budget credibility) and a B on only 3. It was given a C on 8 indicators, C+ on 9, 
D+ on 7, and D (the lowest grade) on 3.8 Although some budget and fiscal management 
indicators  scored  relatively  well,  the  assessment  points  to  poor  performance  in  budget 
classification,  transparency  of  intergovernmental  fiscal  relations,  oversight  of  fiscal  risks  of 
public sector entities, and the extent of unreported government operations. The PEFA results 
were echoed in a country fiduciary risk assessment (FRA) by the Department for International 
Development of the United Kingdom (DFID) in 2008.9 This led the Government of Nepal to 
acknowledge the challenges posed by its “high fiduciary risk environment.”10  
 
7.  Weaknesses  in  Nepal’s  public  financial  management  system  at  the  local 
government level. An unofficial study of local financial governance in 2006 indicated that PFM 
deficiencies at the national level are mirrored at the local government level. Although the sample 
of this study at the local government level was neither comprehensive nor representative, the 
findings raised serious concerns. 11 No local government body scored an A, 33% were rated B, 
50% received a C, and 17% a D. These low ratings were based on such PFM shortcomings as 
ineffective internal audits, overpayments, payment without adequate supporting documents, 
exceeding administrative expense limits, weakness in procurement and management of assets 
and inventory, and expenditures that lacked proper approval. 
 
8.  Budget and fiscal management issues at the local government level. Budget and 
fiscal management at the local government level is afflicted by numerous problems. Budget 
preparation is done without participation by the public because local government councils are 
not elected and are run by civil servants and transitional “all-party” mechanisms.  Internal audits 
are irregular and of poor quality due to the absence of qualified staff and poor controls, and both

government for the capital components of budgets are unpredictable and often delayed or 
reduced, leading to postponement of projects and undermining local government planning.  
Poor costing of capital expenditure and asset maintenance is compounded by a lack of output 
and outcome orientation in budgets. Failure to cost services results in poor cost recovery, 
particularly  in  education  and  health,  the  two  sectors  that  account  for  a  majority  of  local 
government spending. The revenues collected by municipalities, which have the most scope 
among local governments for fiscal autonomy, fall well below actual potential because property 
records are incomplete, houses often lack even a proper address, and tax rates are out of date.  
 
9.  Public  procurement  problems.  Sound  public  procurement  plays  a  central  part  in 
effective PFM but the problems with government procurement in Nepal, where it consumes up 
to 80% of the national budget, are severe. Nepal received a C for competition, value for money, 
and controls in the 2008 PEFA assessment (para. 6), which showed little improvement since a 
World Bank country procurement assessment report in 2002.12 A joint working group of the 
government, ADB, DFID, and the World Bank formed in 2008 found the Public Procurement Act 
had major gaps and was ineffectively enforced. Collusion, intimidation, and other bad practices 
had been growing, especially at the local level.13 In January 2012, ADB and the World Bank 
conducted a joint procurement review with the Public Procurement Monitoring Office (PPMO). 
The review confirmed earlier findings and raised concerns about devolution of procurement 
because the capacity to carry it out at local levels remains practically nonexistent.14 
 
10.  Major accountability and oversight issues. The 2009 Global Integrity Report on Nepal 
shows  a  very  large  gap  between  the  laws  and  policies  on  accountability  and  actual 
implementation.  Nepal  ranks  154th  on  Transparency  International’s  2011  Corruption 
Perceptions Index. Long-standing leadership vacuums in accountability agencies, notably the 
Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) and the Office of the Auditor 
General, prevent Nepal from addressing its governance problems squarely. The government’s 
National Vigilance Centre (NVC) remains institutionally weak. Nepal’s laws and regulations to 
combat corruption have large loopholes not only in practice but also on paper. For example, the 
CIAA  has  no  jurisdiction  over  the  judiciary,  the  military,  or  the  private  sector.  With  few 
investigations and convictions of corrupt high-level officials, corruption in Nepal has become a 
low-risk, high-reward activity.15 
 
2.  The Government’s Public Financial Management Reform Program 
 
11.  Government initiatives to address public financial management problems at the 
national level. The government developed a public financial management reform program for 
2009–2012 that focused on six areas: tax collection, budget formulation, budget execution, 
accounting and reporting, external audit, and institutional capacity (footnote 10). Its  taxation 
reforms, institutionalization of a medium-term expenditure framework to link policies to budgets, 
internal and external audits, establishment of a treasury single account, procurement reform, 
and  strengthening  of  the  PEFA  secretariat  are  at  different  stages of  implementation.  With 
respect  to  public  procurement,  the  government  formulated  and  implemented  the  Public 
Procurement Strategic Framework Phase 1, 2010–2013 (footnote 13). 
 
                                                 
12 World Bank. 2002. Nepal Country Procurement Assessment Report. Washington, DC (April). 
13 Government of Nepal, Office of the Prime Minister and Council of Ministers, Public Procurement Monitoring Office. 
2010. Nepal Public Procurement Strategic Framework, Phase 1: 2010–2013. Kathmandu (July). 
14 ADB. 2012. 3rd Joint World Bank and ADB Public Procurement Review Mission: A Technical Note. Manila (March). 
15 Sarah Dix. 2011. Corruption and Anti-Corruption in Nepal. Oslo (June).

4 
12.  Government reforms to tackle public financial management issues at the local 
government level. The government’s local governance and capacity development program 
(LGCDP) for 2008–2014 has spearheaded local governance reforms.16 ADB, through its Nepal 
Governance Support Program,17 supported the LGCDP under a joint financing arrangement with 
five other development partners.18 The LGCDP has become an important national program for 
reducing  poverty  and  tackling  social  exclusion.  It  established  a  framework  to  consolidate 
fragmented donor assistance and streamlined fiscal transfers to local government bodies. This 
has led to improved local service delivery even in difficult areas. To guard against fiduciary risks, 
the LGCDP supported social mobilization activities to empower community-level groups such as 
ward  citizen  forums  and  citizen  action  centers  to  participate  in  local  government  decision 
making and make up for the absence of local elected officials. This approach was coupled with 
outcome-based monitoring to hold local governments accountable, notably through a framework 
of minimum conditions and performance measures (MC&PM) for DDCs. 
 
13.  Emergence of fiduciary risks in local governance. The midterm report on the LGCDP 
found fiduciary risks in its implementation.19 An FRA of local governance conducted in response 
by ADB and its development partners20 found a lack of transparency and political interference in 
budget allocations, poor accounting and reporting, noncompliance with procurement regulations, 
and the absence of internal and external audits. Development partners also financed a public 
expenditure  tracking  survey  (PETS)  of  the  LGCDP  to  better  understand  the  sources  and 
severity of fiduciary risks. The findings reflected the results of the FRA.21 A focused evaluation 
of the LGCDP by the Ministry of Federal Affairs and Local Development (MOFALD) in July 2012 
called  for  new  policies  to  reduce  fiduciary  risks. 22  Just  as  important  as  the  fiduciary 
shortcomings is the fact that central government policies are not enforced and, therefore, not 
credible and local stakeholders lack incentives to implement them.   
 
14.  The government’s response to fiduciary risks. The MOFALD approved a fiduciary 
risk reduction action plan (FRRAP) in March 2012 to respond to the findings on the problem 
(para. 13). The FRRAP reflects lessons learned from implementing the LGCDP, notably the 
importance of strengthening PFM systems at the local level, ensuring results-oriented capacity 
building in PFM in local government bodies, and bolstering social mobilization approaches.23 By 
focusing on local governance reforms, the FRRAP complements national-level PFM reforms 
being supported by the PFM Multi-Donor Trust Fund (MDTF).24

15.  Mobilization of multilateral and bilateral support for the government’s reforms. 
ADB mobilized additional resources to cofinance the program and support the government’s 
wide-ranging PFM reforms. It has secured cofinancing from DFID of $6.5 million equivalent. A 
separate  cofinancing  proposal  for  €4.5  million  by  the  European  Union  (EU)  is  also  being 
discussed. Because the EU decision may not be made until December 2012, only the DFID 
contribution is reflected in this Report and Recommendation of the President. The program has 
received strong endorsement by the local governance donor group and the PFM donor group 
co-chaired by the EU and the World Bank. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The  program’s  expected  impact  will  be  more  effective  delivery  of  public  goods  and 
services in Nepal, especially at the local government  level. The intended outcome is enhanced 
efficiency, transparency, and integrity of public finances at the national and sub-national levels. 
 
C.  Outputs 
17.  The  program  outputs  will  be  (i)  improved  local  government  budget  and  fiscal 
management, (ii) strengthened fiduciary risk management at the local government level, (iii) an 
enhanced  public  procurement  system,  and  (iv)  strengthened  oversight  and  accountability 
institutions. These outputs will be achieved through four component sets of activities. A policy 
matrix of policy actions that serve as performance triggers for disbursements is in Appendix 4. 
 
18.  Component 1: Local government budget and fiscal management. The program will 
support government efforts to foster more effective local government budget and expenditure 
management  and  fiscal  sustainability.  These  reforms  include  (i)  strengthening  participatory 
planning processes to help enforce implementation of local governance guidelines, including 
allocation of block grants and funding for women, children, and disadvantaged groups; (ii) 
introducing performance-based grants for VDCs; (iii) enhancing timely budget disbursements to 
local governments by applying a medium-term budget framework for DDCs and municipalities; 
(v) institutionalizing results-based management for local governments through the development 
of a results framework and the introduction of annual performance plans for local officials; and 
(vi)  enhancing  revenue  management  of  municipalities  through  the  piloting  of  a  municipal 
administration revenue system (MARS) to increase their ability to raise their own revenues and 
to improve tax compliance by better application of incentives and penalties. 
 
19.  Component 2:  Fiduciary risk management at the local government level. The 
program will support government reforms to reduce fiduciary risks and strengthen safeguards in 
local governance. These reforms include (i) strengthening local government accounting systems 
through  computerization  of  accounting  systems  in  DDCs,  municipalities,  and  VDCs;  (ii) 
improving  management  and  accountability  of  user  groups  through  public  auditing;  (iii) 
strengthening  civic  oversight  through  capacity  building  of  ward  citizen  forums  and  citizen 
awareness centers, as well as adoption of guidelines on public and social audits; (iv) enhancing 
transparency  in  local  governance  through  development  of  websites  that  will  disclose  local 
government  revenues  and  expenditures;  (v)  reinforcing  oversight  mechanisms  of  MOFALD 
through support for its good governance unit; and (vi) strengthening external and internal audits 
                                                                                                                                                          
capacity building for the Office of the Auditor General, (iii) the fostering of demand-side capacity building, (iv) 
research on implementation of audit recommendations, and (v) a PETS of the education sector.

6 
of local governments through the formulation and implementation of auditing guidelines and 
development of an audit clearance tracking system. 
 
20.  Component  3:  Public  procurement  reform. The program will support government 
efforts to increase safeguards in public procurement by making it more transparent, competitive, 
and efficient. It will specifically support public procurement reforms at the local level proposed in 
the FRRAP. These include the establishment of procurement units in DDCs and municipalities, 
the  development  of  annual  procurement  plans  in  local  governments,  the  preparation  and 
implementation  of  procurement  master  plans  for  local  governments,  the  development  of 
standard bidding documents in Nepali for procurement at the VDC level, and capacity building 
of  procurement  staff  in  DDCs  and  municipalities.  Support  for  the  development  of  an  e-
government procurement (e-GP) system will be provided through the program’s associated TA. 
 
21.  Component 4: Oversight and accountability capacity building. The program will 
support the government’s efforts to strengthen its oversight and accountability functions. The 
program will support the government’s National Strategy against Corruption 2012, including the 
Anti-Corruption Strategy and Work Plan of the NVC. It will also help the NVC strengthen its 
technical audit capacity and expand its corruption prevention tools. The program’s associated 
TA will support the development of a corruption vulnerability diagnostic instrument that can be 
used to assess the corruption risks and safeguards of public investment projects.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
24.  The PEFA steering committee will be the steering committee for and will provide policy 
guidance to the program. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the program executing agency 
and will be responsible for the overall implementation of the program, including compliance with 
all policy actions, facility administration, disbursements and maintenance of records. The MOF 
will receive support from the PEFA Secretariat, which will serve as the PMU, and provide: (i) 
technical  guidance  to  the  Implementing  Agencies,  (ii)  periodically  review  the  progress  of 
program  implementation,  and  (iii)  ensure  coordination  of  the  program  with  other  reform

7 
initiatives.  MOFALD,  PPMO  and  NVC  will  be  the  implementing  agencies.  MOFALD  will 
implement components 1 and 2 of the program, PPMO will implement component 3 of the 
program and NVC will implement component 4 of the program. PPMO and NVC, respectively, 
will  establish  a  PCU  to  implement  their  respective  components.  The  existing  program 
coordination unit for LGCDP in MOFALD shall serve as the PCU for MOFALD. Each PCU will 
have  a  manager  and  will:  (i)  supervise  implementation  of  activities  under  their  respective 
component, (ii) prepare and submit progress reports to the program executing agency and PMU, 
and (iii) liaise with the PEFA Secretariat in the implementation of the program.  
 
25.  The program will be implemented over 3 years from November 2012 to October 2015. 
The grant proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with the provisions of ADB’s Simplification 
of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans.25  The proceeds 
will finance the foreign exchange costs, excluding taxes and duties, of items produced and 
procured in ADB member countries and exclude items on the list of ineligible items and imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. No supporting import documentation will be 
required if, during each year that grant proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value of 
Nepal’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and 
disbursements made under other official development assistance, is greater than the amount of 
the grant expected to be disbursed during such year. The government will certify its compliance 
with  this  formula  in  each  withdrawal  request.  Other  import  documentation  under  existing 
procedures will be required. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of grant proceeds and verify 
the accuracy of the government’s certification. The implementation arrangements are in Table 2.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
26.  ADB will provide a capacity development TA for Supporting the Strengthening Public 
Management Program to help the government achieve the policy reforms outlined in the policy 
matrix. The TA will also support the development and pilot implementation of MARS and the e-
GP system. The TA project will have the same intended impact and outcome as the project, 
which are to be achieved through the following outputs: 
 
27.  Output 1: Key public financial management diagnostic tools. The TA will support 
the implementation of key activities in the policy matrix. This will include two public expenditure 
tracking surveys—the first at midterm and the second towards the end of the program—and a 
                                                 
25 ADB. 1998. Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans. Manila.

8 
PEFA assessment at the local government level that preferably will be undertaken at the same 
time as a national PEFA assessment. The TA will also support the development of a framework 
of MC&PM for VDCs. 26 The TA will help the PMU (FCGO) coordinate these activities. 
 
28.  Output 2: Municipal administration revenue system. The TA will develop MARS and 
pilot it in at least one municipality. The MARS will enable municipalities to raise more of their 
own revenues, particularly from such sources as the house and land tax and the integrated 
property tax. By establishing an electronic database of taxable houses and land and taxpayers, 
MARS  will  widen  the  municipal  tax  base  and  enhance  tax  compliance.  The  revenue 
management and financial planning module of MARS will be designed to exchange data with 
the government’s integrated financial management information system. 
 
29.  Output 3: E-government procurement system. Building on the current ADB TA to the  
PPMO, the  TA  will  develop  a  full-fledged  e-GP  system  to  cover  all  aspects  of  the  public 
procurement cycle and will support the rollout of the e-submission module of e-GP to at least 
eight  ministries.27 The  complete  e-GP  system  to  be  developed  will  include  electronic  bid 
evaluation,  contract  award,  contract  administration,  and  payments;  creation  of  online 
catalogues; and measures for enabling procurement performance analysis and auditing. The TA 
will also help develop e-GP training modules. 
 
30.  The TA will be implemented together with the program through three consulting services 
packages. Package 1 will support attainment of key policy actions, notably the PETS and the 
PEFA surveys, and the formulation of the MC&PM framework. Packages 2 and 3 will be for the 
development of MARS and e-GP system, respectively, and will include procurement of hardware 
and software. Due to the highly technical nature of these activities, the firm recruitment will use the 
quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  with  a  standard  quality-cost  ratio  of  90:10.  All 
consultants will be recruited in line with ADB’s Guidelines on Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). All procurement of goods and services will follow ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). At the end of the TA, all equipment procured 
will be retained by the government. All disbursements will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).28 
 
31.  The cost of the TA is  estimated at the equivalent of $3,000,000.29 The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV) in the amount 
of $500,000, and cofinanced by the Government of the United Kingdom in an amount equivalent 
to $2,500,000, to be administered by ADB. Additional cofinancing has been sought from the EU 
that, if approved, will be utilized to expand the scope of the TA to support public procurement 
capacity building and other PFM reforms (paras. 27–29). 30 
                                                 
26 The program will also draw on the United Nations Capital Development Fund’s work on accrual accounting, 
strengthening of expenditure reporting, studies on block grant guidelines, and formula-based grant allocations. 
27 The  TA  will  build  on  the  small-scale  TA  on  Strengthening  Public  Procurement  Management  and  Portfolio 
Performance being implemented by ADB’s Nepal Resident Mission. TA 7752 
28 The TA packages, implementation schedule, and budget are in the Technical Assistance for Supporting the Public 
Management Reform Program: Terms of Reference and Cost Estimates (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2). 
29 Technical Assistance for Supporting the Strengthening Public Management Program: Terms of Reference and 
Cost Estimates (accessible from the list of limited documents in Appendix 2).  
30 Subject to EU parliamentary approval, the EU Delegation to Nepal has indicated it can provide co-financing of €4.5 
million for the TA. In the event this co-financing is approved, the scale of the Program and TA will be expanded as 
follows: (i) expansion of e-GP rollout to 1 or 2 additional other ministries and agencies; (ii) greater coverage of 
public procurement capacity building; (iii) MARS rollout to 1 other municipality and additional training on MARS; 
and (iv) implementation of additional internal audit capacity building and support for the FCGO’s PMU functions.

9 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
32.  The highly technical components of the program pertain to the MARS and e-GP systems. 
A two-step assessment was conducted for these activities. The first was an as-is analysis of the 
issues facing municipal finance and public procurement. The second was a to-be analysis for 
the proposed interventions, including scope of work, timing, and costing. The program drew on 
the findings of the third ADB–World Bank procurement review mission completed in March 2012. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
33.  The main benefits from component 1 will be improved management of central transfers 
to local governments and enhanced ability of local governments - municipalities using MARS in 
particular - to mobilize their own revenues.31 Benefits under component 2 will be a reduction in 
financial irregularities and improvements in public service delivery as a result of improved 
accounting  systems  and  results-based  management.  Wider  public  participation  in  local 
government budgeting and accounting, and more effective auditing will also reduce irregularities. 
Component 3 benefits will be expenditure savings of about $20 million per year from lower costs, 
better pricing, and higher quality goods and services due to more competitive and transparent 
public  procurement.  Benefits  under  component  4  will  come  in  the  form  of  a  reduction  of 
government arrears of about $7 million annually. Overall, these benefits strongly justify program 
costs. Moreover, the increased stream of municipal revenues and cost savings will strengthen 
fiscal positions at both national and local levels and incentivize further reforms. 
 
C.   Governance 
 
34.  A  governance  risk  assessment  in  line  with  ADB's  Second  Governance  and 
Anticorruption Action Plan was carried out.32 The assessment complements studies by the DFID 
and the World Bank. The government unveiled a PFM reform program in 2009 and developed a 
public procurement strategy framework in July 2010. The government has passed the following 
anti-corruption legislation: the Good Governance Act of 2008, the Right to Information Act of 
2007, the Public Procurement Act of 2007, and the Anti-Money-Laundering Act of 2008. A risk 
assessment  and  risk  management  plan  has  been  developed  for  the  program  to  mitigate 
governance risks.33 In addition, ADB’s Anticorruption and Policy (1998, as amended to date) 
was explained to and discussed with the government. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
35.  The program will benefit poor and marginalized groups, including women and children. 
Local government budget and fiscal management reforms will ensure more timely and reliable 
fiscal transfers of funds to support gender empowerment and social inclusion (GESI) objectives. 
A key policy action of the program will be to demonstrate implementation of earmarked funding 
for GESI activities according to the government’s guidelines—15% for disadvantaged groups, 
                                                 
31 A base case scenario of revenue gains in a medium-sized municipality shows an increase of $8 million–$11 million 
on a cumulative basis in the first 5 years after introduction of MARS. This is based on an assumption of an annual 
5% increase in the number of houses registered and an increase in the tax compliance rate from the current level 
of 30% to around 90% in 5 years. Also see Financial and Economic Analysis (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2). 
32 ADB. 2006. Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan. Manila. 
33 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
10%  for  women,  and  10%  for  children.  Downward  accountability  mechanisms  in  budget 
preparation will ensure that local projects are aligned with GESI goals. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
36.  The program’s reforms do not involve physical construction activities and an adverse 
impact on the environment, involuntary resettlement, or indigenous peoples is unlikely. The 
program is thus classified as category C in all three of ADB’s safeguard areas.  
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
37.  The governance risk assessment carried out for ADB’s Nepal CPS 2010–2012 identified 
risks in PFM, procurement, and corruption. Mitigating measures to address these risks are 
outlined in the risk assessment and risk management plan (footnote 33). In addition, to guard 
against procurement risks in program implementation, it is ADB through the TA that will conduct 
the procurement for the e-GP and MARS systems. With respect to consultants who will be 
engaged by MOFALD, ADB will be consulted in their selection. This consultation is not required 
under the program modality but it has been added as a risk mitigating measure. Finally, ADB 
and its development partners are regularly engaged in dialogue with the government and have 
had a strong track record in securing government responsiveness to address fiduciary risks 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
38.  The government and the MOF have assured ADB that implementation of the program 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement, as described in detail 
in the program implementation arrangements and grant documents. 
 
39.  The grant will become effective after all conditions for the release of the first tranche of 
the program, as specified in the policy matrix and set out in Attachment 2 to Schedule 2 of the 
grant agreement, have been complied with, to the satisfaction of ADB. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the  grant  not  exceeding  $21,000,000  to  Nepal  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources, for the Strengthening Public Management Program, on terms and 
conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft 
grant agreement presented to the Board; 
(ii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$4,000,000 to Nepal for the Strengthening Public Management Program, to be 
provided by the Government of the United Kingdom; and 
(iii)  the administration by ADB of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $2,500,000 to the Government of Nepal for Supporting the Strengthening 
Public Management Program to be provided by the Government of the United 
Kingdom on a grant basis. 
 
Haruhiko V. Kuroda 
President 
4 September 2012
